content: The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows for expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions under the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriations Act by transmitting a special message to Congress within 3 days of the Act's enactment. The President must include a draft bill or joint resolution for each item of budget authority proposed for rescission. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriations Act by transmitting a special message to Congress within 3 days of the Act's enactment. The special message must include a draft bill or joint resolution for each item of budget authority proposed for rescission, specifying certain details. Procedures for expedited consideration by Congress are also outlined. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriations Act by transmitting a special message to Congress within 3 days of the Act's enactment. The majority or minority leader of the House must introduce the draft bill or joint resolution accompanying the special message within two days of receipt, or any Member can introduce it on the third day. The bill or joint resolution is then referred to the Committee on Appropriations for further action. The bill or joint resolution introduced after receiving a special message must be referred to the Committee on Appropriations of the House. The committee must report the bill without substantive revision within seven days of receiving the message. If the committee fails to report the bill within this period, it will be automatically discharged, and the bill will be placed on the calendar for consideration. The Committee on Appropriations must report the bill or joint resolution within seven days of receiving a special message. Failure to do so will result in automatic discharge from consideration, and the bill will be placed on the calendar for a vote on final passage within 10 days of continuous session. The Clerk of the House of Representatives or the Secretary of the Senate must engross, certify, and transmit a bill or joint resolution to the other House of Congress on the same day it is agreed to. The bill or joint resolution will be referred to the Committee on Appropriations for reporting within seven days without substantive revision. The bill or joint resolution must be reported by the Committee on Appropriations without substantive revision within seven days. If the committee fails to do so, they will be discharged from consideration, and the bill will be placed on the calendar for a vote within 10 days. The bill or joint resolution must be voted on within 10 days of being transmitted to the House, and if agreed to, it will be returned to the originating House. A motion in the House of Representatives to consider a bill or joint resolution must be made. The House of Representatives must vote on a bill or joint resolution within 10 days of receiving it from the Senate. A motion to consider a bill or joint resolution in the House is highly privileged, not debatable, and limited to 4 hours of debate. Amendments to the motion are not allowed, and further debate limitations are also not debatable. Debate in the House of Representatives on a bill or joint resolution under this section is limited to 4 hours, divided equally between those in favor and those opposing. Appeals from decisions of the Chair regarding the Rules of the House are decided without debate. Consideration of the bill or joint resolution is subject to specific provisions in this subsection. Appeals from decisions of the Chair on House Rules for bills under this section are decided without debate. Consideration of bills or joint resolutions is governed by House Rules. In the Senate, a motion to proceed on a bill under this section is privileged and not debatable. Amendments to the motion are not allowed, nor is reconsideration of the vote on the motion. Debate on bills or joint resolutions under this section in the Senate is limited to 10 hours, divided equally between the majority and minority leaders. Debates on motions or appeals are restricted to 1 hour, divided between the mover and the bill's manager. Debate in the Senate on debatable motions or appeals regarding a bill or joint resolution under this section is limited to 1 hour, divided between the mover and the bill's manager. The minority leader or designee controls the time in opposition if the manager is in favor. Additional time can be allotted by the leaders during consideration. A motion to further limit debate on a bill or joint resolution is not debatable in the Senate. "(D) Additional time can be allotted by leaders during consideration of a bill or joint resolution. No amendments are allowed, and motions to further limit debate or recommit are not debatable. Any amount must be made available for obligation." The resolution considered under this section can be in either the House of Representatives or the Senate. No motion to suspend this subsection is allowed in either House, nor can it be suspended by unanimous consent. Any budget authority proposed for rescission must be available for obligation the day after either House defeats the bill or joint resolution. Definitions for this section include the term 'appropriation Act' and the continuity of a session of Congress. The term 'appropriation Act' is defined as any general or special appropriation Act, including supplemental, deficiency, or continuing appropriations. The continuity of a session of Congress is considered broken only by an adjournment sine die, with days of adjournment over 3 days excluded in the calculation of continuous session periods. The text discusses the transmission of special messages during Congress sessions and the commencement of continuous session periods.
